conclusion: Consider the forces acting on the piston and the cylinder to determine the maximum distance the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder when the elevator moves vertically.
Calculate the weight of the piston as W = m * g = 3 kg * 10 m/s^2 = 30 N.
The atmospheric pressure is p0 = 1.0 x 10^5 Pa.
The maximum tension the rope can withstand is F = 120 N.
The friction between the piston and the cylinder wall is negligible, and the thickness of the piston is also negligible, so there is no friction force acting on the piston.
Calculate the net force acting on the piston as F_net = W - T = 30 N - 120 N = -90 N.
Since the net force is negative, the piston is being pulled downward by the rope.
Determine the maximum distance the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder as d_max = F_net / W = -90 N / 30 N = -3 m.
Since the distance cannot be negative, the maximum distance that the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder is 3 m.
The maximum distance that the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder when the elevator moves along the vertical direction is 3 m.
